info.title: Paged Media with the DocBook xslTNG Stylesheets

abstract.para: A brief introduction to formatting paged media with the DocBook xslTNG Stylesheets.

revision.revremark: Tightned the focus on paged media.

chapter.title: What is DocBook?
chapter.para: DocBook is a very widely used XML vocabulary maintained by the DocBook Technical Committee of OASIS. It is particularly well suited to books and papers about computer hardware and software (though it is by no means limited to these applications).

listitem.para: Hierarchy: set, book, chapter, appendix, refentry, bibliography, glossary, index, …
Blocks: section, para, table, figure, example, equation, programlisting, cmdsynopsis, classsynopsis, …
Inlines: emphasis, filename, replaceable, foreignphrase, methodname, mousebutton, …

chapter.para: DocBook started as an SGML DTD more than 30 years ago. It is now an XML vocabulary defined normatively by a RELAX NG grammar and Schematron rules.

chapter.title: Styling DocBook
chapter.para: The DocBook xslTNG Stylesheets are the thirdfifth generation of stylesheets that I’ve worked on for transforming DocBook into HTML and print. Before them there were:

listitem.para: The DocBook XSLT 2.0 Stylesheets, circa 2010. (Paged media story: weak)
The DocBook XSLT 1.0 Stylesheets, circa 2000 (still maintained). (Paged media story: XSL Formatting Objects)
The DocBook DSSSL Stylesheets, circa 1996. (Paged media story: part of the processor)
The gmat formatter (successor to fmat), circa 1994. (Paged media story: it generated troff markup from a recursive descent parse of the object tree. The less said, the better.)

(It was a bailing wire, duct tape, and chewing gum hack that I co-wrote for O’Reilly. It used objects in some early beta of Perl 5 to build a parse tree of the SGML ESIS from DocBook (1.x? 2.x?) sources.)

chapter.title: What is DocBook xslTNG?
chapter.para: The DocBook xslTNG Stylesheets are XSLT 3.0 stylesheets for transforming DocBook to HTML. The goals are:

listitem.para: Clean, semantic HTML
That looks good “out of the box” (on the web or in print)
With good accessibility hooks
That is easy to style (in large part, perhaps, because of the efforts to generate clean HTML)

chapter.para: The standard distribution also includes extension functions to perform XInclude processing, syntax highlighting of verbatim environments, extract metadata from images, and even perform some validation.

chapter.title: Five Interesting Things
chapter.para: If you’re interested in seeing more generally what the DocBook xslTNG Stylesheets can do online, see Five Interesting Things.
(P.S. There are at least seven interesting things now!)

chapter.title: Multi-stage transformation
chapter.para: Multi-stage transformation makes the processing simpler:

listitem.para: Cleanup the logical structure
Perform XInclude processing
(Convert DocBook 4.x to 5.x)
Perform DocBook Transclusion
Profile with effectivity attributes
Normalize markup
Process annotations
Apply XLink linkbases
(Validate with RELAX NG)
Transform to HTML (for online or paged media)

chapter.para: The last stage is always operating on consistent markup.

listitem.para: The stylesheets can produce three different kinds of output: a single-page HTML document (the “natural” transformation of a DocBook document into an HTML document), a multi-page HTML document (“chunked” output), or HTML designed for use in paged media.
As much as possible, we want to avoid caring about this in the DocBook-to-HTML transformation. The “core” xslTNG transformation is agnostic to the output type.
Document features that need to be rendered differently (annotations, footnotes, etc.) are not in their final form in the initial HTML output.
A small customization layer is provided for tailoring the output to paged media. This includes applying different CSS, for example.

The HTML is transformed with a target in mind: for paged media, it generates HTML that can be styled appropriately for bottom-of-the-page footnotes, for example, and can add page numbers to cross references.
